task.summary: Trying to get this git garbage to work. Also some pictures showing the insanity. Each one only shows major differences in one color. The pictures were created through the nasty for loop and by changing the x's of the (x vals: 0,1,2) if i % 3 == x and the order of them. Why would that change the color that has the details in it?

Each picture only shows major differences in one color. The pictures were created through the nasty for loop and by changing the x's of the (x vals: 0,1,2) if i % 3 == x and the order of them. Why would that change the color that has the details in it?
:::::::PROBLEM FOUND AND FIXED:::::::
In the current code there are (naught, one, two) _count variables. In the previous code it was just one variable count. This variable was intended to be used in the update_pixel function to update which row the pixel was taken from. (You want to take the pixel from one row three times to get the proper picture). Count would reset each time it hit nine, as would row. The problem was that count would only hit nine during one color, so only one color would change its row. The other colors would be stuck on the same row forever. The fix was simple, and easy. Use three different variables, duhhh. This now works.
:::::::::FUTURE DEVELOPMENT:::::: -find the colors of perlers available, create a palette out of them.
-implement a dithering function with the perler.
-clean up this awful code.

The pictures show an old bug.
:::::::NEW STUFF::::::::: The code is cleaned up a little bit. I still wonder if I could make the pixel_scatter function prettier. It's pretty big right now. Added a pixel_scatter example image.
:::::::past problems fixed:::::::
In the current code there are (blue, green, red) _count variables. In the previous code it was just one variable count. This variable was intended to be used in the update_pixel_count function to update which row the pixel was taken from. (You want to take the pixel from one row three times to get the proper picture). Count would reset each time it hit nine, and row would increase. The problem was that count would only hit nine during one color, so only one color would change its row. The other colors would be stuck on the same row forever. The fix was simple, and easy. Use three different variables, duhhh. This has been working.
:::::::::FUTURE DEVELOPMENT:::::: -find the colors of perlers available, create a palette out of them.
-implement a dithering function with the perler.

BUG FIX function slash line 67
old code: if num_shades < 1:
new code: if num_shades > 1:
this line of code checks for dividing by zero, and values that don't make sense and prevents those problems. The old code made it so this function would only try to run if you provided a number that didn't make sense.

The pictures were created through the nasty for loop and by changing the x's of the (x vals: 0,1,2) if i % 3 == x and the order of them. Why would that change the color that has the details in it?

Each picture only shows major differences in one color. The pictures were created through the nasty for loop and by changing the x's of the (x vals: 0,1,2) if i % 3 == x and the order of them. Why would that change the color that has the details in it?
:::::::PROBLEM FOUND AND FIXED:::::::
In the current code there are (naught, one, two) _count variables. In the previous code it was just one variable count. This variable was intended to be used in the update_pixel function to update which row the pixel was taken from. (You want to take the pixel from one row three times to get the proper picture). Count would reset each time it hit nine, as would row. The problem was that count would only hit nine during one color, so only one color would change its row. The other colors would be stuck on the same row forever. The fix was simple, and easy. Use three different variables, duhhh. This now works.

:::::::past problems fixed:::::::
In the current code there are (blue, green, red) _count variables. In the previous code it was just one variable count. This variable was intended to be used in the update_pixel_count function to update which row the pixel was taken from. (You want to take the pixel from one row three times to get the proper picture). Count would reset each time it hit nine, and row would increase. The problem was that count would only hit nine during one color, so only one color would change its row. The other colors would be stuck on the same row forever. The fix was simple, and easy. Use three different variables, duhhh. This has been working.
:::::::::FUTURE DEVELOPMENT:::::: -find the colors of perlers available, create a palette out of them.
-implement a dithering function with the perler.

this line of code checks for dividing by zero, and values that don't make sense and prevents those problems. The old code made it so this function would only try to run if you provided a number that didn't make sense.
